data: 1 00:01:39,701 --> 00:01:41,803 (HEART BEATING STEADILY) 2 00:01:46,507 --> 00:01:48,876 (MACHINE GUN FIRING) 3 00:01:52,580 --> 00:01:53,581 (WOMAN PANTING) 4 00:01:54,281 --> 00:01:55,917 (EXPLOSION) 5 00:01:55,950 --> 00:01:57,952 -(HEART BEATING CONTINUES) -(MAN SHOUTING INDISTINCTLY) 6 00:02:02,857 --> 00:02:04,257 (WOMAN PANTING) 7 00:02:06,894 --> 00:02:08,128 (MACHINE GUN FIRE) 8 00:02:09,429 --> 00:02:10,598 (BREATHING HEAVILY) 9 00:02:13,735 --> 00:02:14,769 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKS) 10 00:02:14,802 --> 00:02:18,072 (EXPLOSION) 11 00:02:34,956 --> 00:02:36,924 (HIGH-PITCHED RINGING) 12 00:02:38,893 --> 00:02:41,863 (DISTORTED SHOUTING) 13 00:02:41,896 --> 00:02:43,296 JONESY: We have to move. Come on! 14 00:02:44,331 --> 00:02:48,102 Bombs blasted. Soldiers were shot. 15 00:02:48,136 --> 00:02:49,737 (GLASS CLANKING) 16 00:02:49,771 --> 00:02:51,039 YOUNG MAN: Yes. I expect those things 17 00:02:51,072 --> 00:02:52,372 would happen in a war. 18 00:02:52,406 --> 00:02:53,373 Well, if you know, 19 00:02:54,307 --> 00:02:55,576 then no reason for me 20 00:02:55,610 --> 00:02:57,612 to keep answering your questions. 21 00:02:57,645 --> 00:02:59,714 YOUNG MAN: Did you answer one? I must've missed it. 22 00:03:05,520 --> 00:03:06,988 What do you expect to get from this? 23 00:03:08,288 --> 00:03:10,124 "Get from this"? 24 00:03:10,158 --> 00:03:11,592 If you think that's a difficult question, 25 00:03:11,626 --> 00:03:14,629 you might want to reconsider your future in journalism. 26 00:03:15,830 --> 00:03:16,831 I'm curious. 27 00:03:17,832 --> 00:03:18,966 LEE: That never bodes well. 28 00:03:19,934 --> 00:03:20,902 Well, maybe for you. 29 00:03:26,941 --> 00:03:28,543 You're making a big deal out of nothing. 30 00:03:29,342 --> 00:03:30,410 They're just pictures. 31 00:03:30,444 --> 00:03:32,513 I don't believe that. (SIGHS) 32 00:03:32,547 --> 00:03:34,015 There must be stories behind them. 33 00:03:34,682 --> 00:03:35,683 Why does it matter? 34 00:03:36,818 --> 00:03:37,819 YOUNG MAN: They should be heard. 35 00:03:40,955 --> 00:03:42,389 Don't you want the world to know about you? 36 00:03:44,559 --> 00:03:45,927 (LIGHTER CLICKING) 37 00:03:45,960 --> 00:03:47,360 Well, isn't that why you went there? 38 00:03:51,566 --> 00:03:54,669 You think I went to war so people would know my name? 39 00:03:54,702 --> 00:03:57,270 -I didn't say that. -I think you did. 40 00:03:57,304 --> 00:03:58,773 I'm not trying to interrogate you. 41 00:03:58,806 --> 00:04:00,675 All interviews are interrogations. 42 00:04:01,642 --> 00:04:02,744 The good ones, anyway. 43 00:04:05,179 --> 00:04:06,614 Were all of these published? 44 00:04:07,515 --> 00:04:09,684 -Some were. -But not all? 45 00:04:12,720 --> 00:04:13,721 (EXHALES) 46 00:04:14,989 --> 00:04:15,957 What do I get? 47 00:04:16,691 --> 00:04:18,391 What do you mean? 48 00:04:18,425 --> 00:04:19,827 I tell you about these pictures. 49 00:04:19,861 --> 00:04:21,729 I give you all of my stories. 50 00:04:22,563 --> 00:04:23,931 What do I get in return? 51 00:04:24,932 --> 00:04:26,534 (CHUCKLES) 52 00:04:28,603 --> 00:04:30,805 Does it have to be so transactional? 53 00:04:30,838 --> 00:04:32,272 Well, that's what life is. 54 00:04:41,916 --> 00:04:42,917 (GLASS THUDS) 55 00:04:45,753 --> 00:04:47,255 I'll tell you a story about me 56 00:04:47,287 --> 00:04:48,890 if you'll tell me a story about you. 57 00:04:54,562 --> 00:04:56,063 Fine. 58 00:04:56,097 --> 00:04:58,431 (UPBEAT MUSIC PLAYING) 59 00:05:01,602 --> 00:05:03,070 LEE: I'd been the model, 60 00:05:03,104 --> 00:05:06,574 I'd been the muse, I'd been the ingenue. 61 00:05:06,607 --> 00:05:08,242 But I was done with all of that. 62 00:05:08,276 --> 00:05:09,342 (WOMEN GIGGLING) 63 00:05:09,376 --> 00:05:10,778 I was good at drinking, 64 00:05:10,812 --> 00:05:12,513 having sex, and taking pictures. 65 00:05:12,547 --> 00:05:14,916 And I did all three as much as I could. 66 00:05:16,150 --> 00:05:17,151 Life was fun. 67 00:05:17,919 --> 00:05:19,287 (WOMAN SPEAKING FRENCH) 68 00:05:25,726 --> 00:05:28,328 (WOMEN LAUGHING) 69 00:05:30,631 --> 00:05:32,667 (IN ENGLISH) Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. 70 00:05:33,935 --> 00:05:35,402 -(WOMEN LAUGHING) -LEE: That's great. 71 00:05:35,435 --> 00:05:36,804 (ENGINE REVVING) 72 00:05:44,812 --> 00:05:49,382 (WOMEN SINGING IN FRENCH) 73 00:05:55,455 --> 00:05:56,489 (WOMEN LAUGHING) 74 00:05:56,524 --> 00:05:59,392 (CONTINUE SINGING IN FRENCH) 75 00:06:01,796 --> 00:06:03,130 (BRAKES SQUEAL) 76 00:06:13,841 --> 00:06:14,976 (LEE SIGHS) 77 00:06:15,009 --> 00:06:16,577 How many arguments do you think they've had 78 00:06:16,611 --> 00:06:18,079 -since we left? -(LEE SCOFFS) 79 00:06:18,112 --> 00:06:20,314 You think they actually got out of bed? 80 00:06:20,348 --> 00:06:21,716 -(SOLANGE CHUCKLES) -Hello? 81 00:06:23,017 --> 00:06:25,485 PAUL: No. He's not a "lunatic". 82 00:06:25,519 --> 00:06:29,123 He's calculated. Evil. And he won't last. 83 00:06:29,156 --> 00:06:30,992 But the Germans seem to love him. 84 00:06:31,025 --> 00:06:32,593 Well, the French do not. 85 00:06:32,627 --> 00:06:34,362 -Vive la France, mon amour. -(IN ENGLISH) Lunch is served. 86 00:06:34,394 --> 00:06:36,764 JEAN: Bravo. Come sit. 87 00:06:36,797 --> 00:06:37,932 Merci. 88 00:06:37,965 --> 00:06:39,000 SOLANGE: Please, no more politics. 89 00:06:40,034 --> 00:06:41,602 So, I was thinking, 90 00:06:41,636 --> 00:06:44,138 we should swim before cocktails this evening. 91 00:06:44,171 --> 00:06:46,274 -Wonderful. I agree. -(JEAN LAUGHS) 92 00:06:46,307 --> 00:06:47,675 But seriously, 93 00:06:47,708 --> 00:06:50,278 France will not stand for his ideas, 94 00:06:50,311 --> 00:06:52,280 we will move against him. 95 00:06:52,313 --> 00:06:54,348 And when that fails, England will be ready 96 00:06:54,382 --> 00:06:56,117 to ride to your rescue once more. 97 00:06:56,150 --> 00:06:58,686 -MAN: Ah. -Darling, you're here! 98 00:06:58,719 --> 00:07:00,655 We were going to send out a search party. 99 00:07:00,688 --> 00:07:03,324 The English love to brag about saving the day. 100 00:07:03,357 --> 00:07:04,692 It helps that you usually wait 101 00:07:04,725 --> 00:07:06,459 until the last second. (CHUCKLES) 102 00:07:06,493 --> 00:07:08,930 (INDISTINCT CHATTERING) 103 00:07:09,730 --> 00:07:11,299 -Roland. -Hi. 104 00:07:11,332 --> 00:07:12,499 MAN RAY: Roland. Welcome. 105 00:07:12,533 --> 00:07:13,768 SOLANGE: Was it a hideously long journey? 106 00:07:14,602 --> 00:07:15,703 ROLAND: From Cassis? 107 00:07:15,736 --> 00:07:17,505 SOLANGE: From London, of course. 108 00:07:17,538 --> 00:07:18,639 ROLAND: I got stuck behind a farmer. 109 00:07:18,673 --> 00:07:20,374 You know Roland, don't you? 110 00:07:20,408 --> 00:07:21,575 If I did, would I like him? 111 00:07:22,410 --> 00:07:24,145 NUSCH: He's quite charming. 112 00:07:24,178 --> 00:07:25,246 LEE: Mm. So I won't get bored 113 00:07:25,279 --> 00:07:27,248 if we continue with this introduction? 114 00:07:27,281 --> 00:07:28,716 NUSCH: I doubt it. 115 00:07:28,749 --> 00:07:30,818 His art gallery is selling your tits and ass. 116 00:07:30,851 --> 00:07:33,154 -(GROUP CHUCKLES) -How much? 117 00:07:33,187 --> 00:07:35,556 Oh. I get to speak for myself? 118 00:07:36,691 --> 00:07:38,526 But clearly not priced high enough. 119 00:07:38,559 --> 00:07:39,961 Sold far too quickly. 120 00:07:41,295 --> 00:07:43,864 I'd like to have held onto them longer. 121 00:07:43,898 --> 00:07:47,535 Suits me. I never did like to hang around. 122 00:07:47,568 --> 00:07:50,571 Haven't you heard? That's what all ex-models do. 123 00:07:50,604 --> 00:07:51,706 They travel the world 124 00:07:51,739 --> 00:07:52,974 and pretend to be someone interesting. 125 00:07:53,774 --> 00:07:55,242 (GROUP LAUGHING) 126 00:07:57,912 --> 00:08:00,848 What about you? Why don't I know you? 127 00:08:00,881 --> 00:08:02,783 Well, I'm not particularly important. 128 00:08:02,817 --> 00:08:04,552 I just peddle their wares. 129 00:08:04,585 --> 00:08:06,387 Well, if you're not that important, 130 00:08:06,420 --> 00:08:08,622 maybe you should cut your commission? 131 00:08:08,656 --> 00:08:10,758 I work night and day for you, my dear man. 132 00:08:10,791 --> 00:08:12,126 Oh. 133 00:08:12,159 --> 00:08:13,461 You don't look like someone who works night and day. 134 00:08:15,062 --> 00:08:16,097 And there's paint on your hands, 135 00:08:16,130 --> 00:08:17,531 so I assume you're also an artist. 136 00:08:19,066 --> 00:08:20,534 I see you don't wash it off, 137 00:08:21,769 --> 00:08:24,205 is that because you want people to know? 138 00:08:24,238 --> 00:08:25,473 Or do you leave it there because you need 139 00:08:25,506 --> 00:08:27,041 to convince yourself that you are? 140 00:08:28,843 --> 00:08:29,977 And you pour your own wine 141 00:08:30,011 --> 00:08:31,645 before asking the host if you could. 142 00:08:32,480 --> 00:08:33,814 (WHISPERING INDISTINCTLY) 143 00:08:33,848 --> 00:08:35,983 I'll bet the members of any major family in England 144 00:08:36,017 --> 00:08:37,685 know your name before you walk through the door. 145 00:08:40,521 --> 00:08:41,722 You're part of the establishment, 146 00:08:41,756 --> 00:08:42,723 and you hate that. 147 00:08:44,091 --> 00:08:45,059 Am I right? 148 00:08:47,795 --> 00:08:51,065 My lot are Quakers. Not exactly establishment. 149 00:08:52,700 --> 00:08:54,168 But otherwise... 150 00:08:55,302 --> 00:08:56,804 She can see us all. 151 00:08:58,272 --> 00:08:59,240 Can I have a go? 152 00:09:00,441 --> 00:09:03,077 -Please. -(SCATTERED CHUCKLES) 153 00:09:03,110 --> 00:09:04,245 MAN RAY: Good luck with that! 154 00:09:06,013 --> 00:09:07,882 Hmm. You... 155 00:09:08,883 --> 00:09:11,520 grew up staunchly middle class, 156 00:09:11,585 --> 00:09:13,154 which means you were poor for the rich people 157 00:09:13,187 --> 00:09:15,356 and rich for the poor people, 158 00:09:15,389 --> 00:09:18,959 so you feel you never fitted in either. 159 00:09:18,993 --> 00:09:20,428 You're used to people getting distracted 160 00:09:20,461 --> 00:09:22,596 just by looking at you. 161 00:09:22,630 --> 00:09:24,265 You've learned to use that. 162 00:09:24,298 --> 00:09:25,933 Which makes you cleverer than most. 163 00:09:27,502 --> 00:09:29,737 You dislike anyone who questions you, 164 00:09:31,806 --> 00:09:34,108 especially when you know you're wrong. 165 00:09:34,141 --> 00:09:35,876 (SOFT PIANO MUSIC PLAYING) 166 00:09:35,910 --> 00:09:36,911 And you have secrets. 167 00:09:39,346 --> 00:09:40,347 Many... 168 00:09:41,682 --> 00:09:42,750 that you'll never share. 169 00:09:45,554 --> 00:09:47,621 -I'm never wrong. -(GROUP LAUGHING) 170 00:09:47,655 --> 00:09:48,789 MAN RAY: That's our Lee. 171 00:09:49,824 --> 00:09:51,459 And I can pour my own wine, too. 172 00:09:52,960 --> 00:09:54,563 -(GLASS CLINKING) -JEAN: Salute! 173 00:09:54,595 --> 00:09:58,032 (GROUP SPEAKING FRENCH) 174 00:10:02,736 --> 00:10:05,106 I've known you almost as long as I've known Jean. 175 00:10:06,407 --> 00:10:08,543 And I love you nearly as much. 176 00:10:10,377 --> 00:10:11,378 We miss you. 177 00:10:12,613 --> 00:10:13,881 Come back to Paris with us. 178 00:10:14,448 --> 00:10:16,050 (SIGHS) 179 00:10:16,083 --> 00:10:18,385 I don't know who I am in Paris any more. 180 00:10:21,188 --> 00:10:22,156 The question is, 181 00:10:24,258 --> 00:10:26,127 who do you want to be now, Lee Miller? 182 00:10:27,428 --> 00:10:30,965 And what are you going to do about that? 183 00:10:52,019 --> 00:10:53,454 (GLASS THUDDING) 184 00:10:53,487 --> 00:10:55,422 (FOOTSTEPS RECEDING) 185 00:11:06,500 --> 00:11:07,502 (LEE SIGHS) 186 00:11:16,243 --> 00:11:19,046 (SOFT PIANO MUSIC PLAYING) 187 00:11:19,079 --> 00:11:20,948 ROLAND: I've seen your work, you know. 188 00:11:21,650 --> 00:11:23,083 (CHUCKLES SOFTLY) 189 00:11:23,117 --> 00:11:24,118 Tits and ass, 190 00:11:25,186 --> 00:11:26,187 I remember. 191 00:11:27,154 --> 00:11:28,657 No, I mean your real work, 192 00:11:30,291 --> 00:11:32,026 your photographic work. 193 00:11:33,093 --> 00:11:34,461 You're really very impressive. 194 00:11:36,030 --> 00:11:37,031 Thank you. 195 00:11:38,265 --> 00:11:40,134 I'd rather take a picture than... 196 00:11:41,368 --> 00:11:42,369 be one. 197 00:11:45,306 --> 00:11:46,307 (LEE MOANS SOFTLY) 198 00:11:49,944 --> 00:11:51,580 Do you mind if I come in? 199 00:11:53,280 --> 00:11:55,482 You've known me for four hours. 200 00:11:57,284 --> 00:11:59,320 Just imagine what I could know after five. 201 00:12:00,454 --> 00:12:01,422 (LEE MOANS) 202 00:12:14,703 --> 00:12:15,704 (BIRDS CHIRPING) 203 00:12:19,907 --> 00:12:20,908 (INHALES) 204 00:12:24,178 --> 00:12:25,179 (SIGHS) 205 00:12:26,814 --> 00:12:27,781 Roland? 206 00:12:33,887 --> 00:12:34,888 Roland? 207 00:12:39,326 --> 00:12:40,294 (SIGHS) 208 00:12:55,009 --> 00:12:55,976 (CHUCKLES) 209 00:13:01,716 --> 00:13:02,883 (SIGHS) 210 00:13:08,122 --> 00:13:10,124 (INDISTINCT CHATTER) 211 00:13:14,261 --> 00:13:15,563 SOLANGE: Ah. 212 00:13:17,031 --> 00:13:17,998 Hello. 213 00:13:19,033 --> 00:13:20,000 LEE: Morning. 214 00:13:22,436 --> 00:13:23,772 (LEE SIGHS) 215 00:13:25,239 --> 00:13:26,273 We were taking bets 216 00:13:26,307 --> 00:13:28,008 on what time we'd see you today. 217 00:13:28,042 --> 00:13:30,210 Mm. Who won? 218 00:13:30,244 --> 00:13:32,446 -Guess. -(LEE CHUCKLES) 219 00:13:32,479 --> 00:13:35,049 Well, he's much less square than I would've thought. 220 00:13:35,082 --> 00:13:37,251 (WOMEN LAUGHING) 221 00:13:37,284 --> 00:13:39,788 (SPEAKING FRENCH) 222 00:13:39,820 --> 00:13:40,888 NUSCH: Ah, he lives. ROLAND: Morning. 223 00:13:40,921 --> 00:13:42,356 (CHUCKLES) 224 00:13:42,389 --> 00:13:43,357 ROLAND: Barely. 225 00:13:44,124 --> 00:13:45,694 -Morning. -LEE: Morning. 226 00:13:51,098 --> 00:13:53,334 -(SOLANGE CHUCKLING) -May I? 227 00:13:54,268 --> 00:13:55,269 Please. 228 00:14:01,576 --> 00:14:03,611 -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) -Now look here. 229 00:14:04,646 --> 00:14:05,680 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 230 00:14:06,947 --> 00:14:07,948 (CHUCKLES) 231 00:14:11,352 --> 00:14:13,354 If I fall down these steps and die, 232 00:14:14,622 --> 00:14:16,390 be sure to say nice things about me. 233 00:14:17,692 --> 00:14:20,260 Don't let Man Ray go on one of his rants. 234 00:14:20,294 --> 00:14:22,096 "She lived as she looked, 235 00:14:22,129 --> 00:14:23,698 "frivolously and with adventure." 236 00:14:24,465 --> 00:14:25,667 I'm not frivolous. 237 00:14:26,934 --> 00:14:28,570 I'm not. (CHUCKLES) 238 00:14:29,537 --> 00:14:30,805 Where should we go from here? 239 00:14:32,206 --> 00:14:33,508 Well... 240 00:14:33,541 --> 00:14:34,609 (EXHALES SHARPLY) 241 00:14:34,642 --> 00:14:36,143 Certainly not back down there. 242 00:14:37,545 --> 00:14:38,546 (SIGHS) 243 00:14:39,681 --> 00:14:40,682 I leave tomorrow. 244 00:14:43,685 --> 00:14:44,686 Come with me to London? 245 00:14:46,721 --> 00:14:47,722 (EXHALES) 246 00:14:50,224 --> 00:14:51,458 When was the last time you spent longer 247 00:14:51,492 --> 00:14:52,861 than a few months in one place? 248 00:14:52,893 --> 00:14:55,530 (SOFT INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC PLAYING) 249 00:14:55,563 --> 00:14:57,632 How can you possibly know all there is to know 250 00:14:57,665 --> 00:14:59,500 if you stay in the same place all the time? 251 00:15:00,735 --> 00:15:02,604 And you find enough purpose in that? 252 00:15:02,637 --> 00:15:05,038 Well, maybe I haven't found anything 253 00:15:05,072 --> 00:15:06,775 interesting enough to keep me around. 254 00:15:08,008 --> 00:15:09,711 Anything or anyone? 255 00:15:11,378 --> 00:15:13,380 (SOFT INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC CONTINUES) 256 00:15:27,662 --> 00:15:29,463 -God. -(ROLAND CHUCKLES) 257 00:15:32,332 --> 00:15:34,134 -LEE: Don't run. -(ROLAND CHUCKLES) 258 00:15:35,369 --> 00:15:36,370 LEE: Well... 259 00:15:42,777 --> 00:15:44,712 -Would you just... -(BOTH CHUCKLING) 260 00:15:52,085 --> 00:15:53,855 ANNOUNCER: This little lady at the Shoe and Leather Fair 261 00:15:53,888 --> 00:15:56,223 is showing off dainty footwear for policemen. 262 00:15:56,256 --> 00:15:57,659 But the serious side of the show 263 00:15:57,692 --> 00:15:59,426 has some very pretty things for you to look at. 264 00:15:59,460 --> 00:16:01,328 And you can look at the shoes too. 265 00:16:01,361 --> 00:16:04,364 -(UPBEAT JAZZ MUSIC PLAYING) -(INDISTINCT CHATTER) 266 00:16:04,398 --> 00:16:06,166 Going from one extreme to the other, 267 00:16:06,200 --> 00:16:08,068 when Hitler has his 48th birthday, 268 00:16:08,101 --> 00:16:10,070 they make a show of it in a big way. 269 00:16:10,103 --> 00:16:11,371 In fact, over there, 270 00:16:11,405 --> 00:16:12,740 the recipe for successful birthday parties 271 00:16:12,774 --> 00:16:14,341 seems to be something like 272 00:16:14,374 --> 00:16:15,877 throw a few hundred men on parade, 273 00:16:15,910 --> 00:16:17,712 present a few dozen colours flapping in the breeze... 274 00:16:17,745 --> 00:16:20,849 -Jesus, look at them all. -They're idiots. 275 00:16:20,882 --> 00:16:22,249 (ANNOUNCER CONTINUES INDISTINCTLY) 276 00:16:22,282 --> 00:16:23,751 ROLAND: But dangerous. 277 00:16:23,785 --> 00:16:25,587 PICASSO: They're all brainwashed. 278 00:16:25,620 --> 00:16:26,888 Not everyone can believe this. 279 00:16:26,921 --> 00:16:29,256 Surely they can see what he is. 280 00:16:29,289 --> 00:16:31,258 PAUL: But they don't. Look at them. 281 00:16:31,291 --> 00:16:32,894 -(CROWD CHEERING) -This is not an act. 282 00:16:32,927 --> 00:16:34,027 PICASSO: The only sane response 283 00:16:34,061 --> 00:16:36,430 to tyranny is to paint. 284 00:16:36,463 --> 00:16:38,432 -To create. -And drink. 285 00:16:38,465 --> 00:16:40,400 PAUL: And write! JEAN: And dance! 286 00:16:40,434 --> 00:16:42,436 (UPBEAT MUSIC PLAYING) 287 00:16:55,617 --> 00:16:57,619 (SERENE INSTRUMENTAL MUSIC PLAYING) 288 00:17:13,500 --> 00:17:14,769 YOUNG MAN: I still don't understand 289 00:17:14,802 --> 00:17:16,236 how none of you saw it coming. 290 00:17:17,605 --> 00:17:18,840 It happened so slowly, 291 00:17:21,475 --> 00:17:23,076 yet kind of overnight. 292 00:17:23,110 --> 00:17:25,145 We woke up one morning 293 00:17:25,178 --> 00:17:27,347 and Hitler was the most powerful man in Europe. 294 00:17:28,950 --> 00:17:31,385 Even as it was happening it didn't feel real. 295 00:17:34,054 --> 00:17:35,222 So what did you do? 296 00:17:38,626 --> 00:17:39,594 Well... 297 00:17:40,962 --> 00:17:42,997 LEE: I got on with my life. 298 00:17:43,031 --> 00:17:45,800 By then, Europe was at war. 299 00:17:45,833 --> 00:17:48,803 But it all seemed a long way from London. 300 00:17:48,836 --> 00:17:52,306 Roland, as an artist and conscientious objector, 301 00:17:52,339 --> 00:17:54,374 had been hired to develop camouflage techniques 302 00:17:54,408 --> 00:17:55,677 for the war effort. 303 00:17:56,644 --> 00:17:58,345 And we felt safe. 304 00:17:58,378 --> 00:18:00,113 -(DOOR CLOSES) -LEE: Roland? 305 00:18:00,147 --> 00:18:01,348 ROLAND: Darling, you're back. 306 00:18:01,381 --> 00:18:03,116 (RADIO PLAYING INDISTINCTLY) 307 00:18:03,150 --> 00:18:04,117 Holy hell. 308 00:18:05,252 --> 00:18:06,588 Your turn. 309 00:18:06,621 --> 00:18:08,056 MAN: (OVER RADIO) Which attacked the Italian... 310 00:18:08,088 --> 00:18:09,724 Please, let me start dinner. 311 00:18:09,757 --> 00:18:10,858 Come on, I've had a breakthrough. 312 00:18:12,594 --> 00:18:14,862 -You promised. -I didn't promise. 313 00:18:14,896 --> 00:18:16,731 I make it a point never to promise anything. 314 00:18:17,999 --> 00:18:19,567 -All right. -(ROLAND CHUCKLES) 315 00:18:20,702 --> 00:18:23,170 -How was town? -Horrible. 316 00:18:23,203 --> 00:18:25,238 It took forever to find a cab. 317 00:18:27,875 --> 00:18:30,444 -Where do you want me? -Right here, please. 318 00:18:31,579 --> 00:18:33,347 MAN: (OVER RADIO) ...a considerable blow 319 00:18:33,380 --> 00:18:35,248 to Mussolini... 320 00:18:35,282 --> 00:18:36,283 You ready? 321 00:18:38,086 --> 00:18:39,087 (SIGHS) 322 00:18:41,221 --> 00:18:44,092 (SIGHS) All right, make me invisible. 323 00:18:44,124 --> 00:18:46,326 If I can make you invisible 324 00:18:46,360 --> 00:18:48,495 -then I can hide anything. -(CHUCKLES) 325 00:18:50,598 --> 00:18:53,067 MAN: (OVER RADIO) ...that the loss of German aircraft 326 00:18:53,101 --> 00:18:54,669 to anti-aircraft defensive... 327 00:18:54,702 --> 00:18:56,370 Be quick, I'm starving. 328 00:18:56,403 --> 00:18:58,072 Queues were dreadful. 329 00:18:58,106 --> 00:18:59,607 But I did find us some butter today. 330 00:18:59,641 --> 00:19:00,775 ROLAND: Mm-hmm. 331 00:19:00,808 --> 00:19:02,342 And they had chilli powder at Fortnum's, 332 00:19:02,376 --> 00:19:03,845 so if we have to eat rats, 333 00:19:03,878 --> 00:19:05,445 at least they'll be well spiced. 334 00:19:05,479 --> 00:19:06,948 (MAN CONTINUES INDISTINCTLY OVER RADIO) 335 00:19:06,981 --> 00:19:08,983 (GENTLE MUSIC PLAYING) 336 00:19:11,719 --> 00:19:14,287 (LEE SIGHS, CHUCKLES) 337 00:19:17,224 --> 00:19:18,860 Concentrate. 338 00:19:18,893 --> 00:19:21,129 That's quite hard to do. 339 00:19:25,800 --> 00:19:26,801 (LEE MOANS SOFTLY) 340 00:19:28,335 --> 00:19:29,971 (SOFTLY) Oh, God. 341 00:19:30,004 --> 00:19:31,105 Oh, Jesus! 342 00:19:44,619 --> 00:19:46,821 -AUDREY: Hmm? -(CECIL SIGHS) 343 00:19:46,854 --> 00:19:48,823 Don't be territorial, Audrey. 344 00:19:49,691 --> 00:19:51,425 Editorial, I think you mean. 345 00:19:51,458 --> 00:19:52,660 (KNOCKING AT DOOR) 346 00:19:52,694 --> 00:19:53,961 Excuse me, Miss Withers. 347 00:19:53,995 --> 00:19:55,129 There's a Lee Miller to see you. 348 00:19:55,163 --> 00:19:56,831 The Lee Miller? 349 00:19:56,864 --> 00:19:58,566 What's she doing in London? 350 00:19:58,599 --> 00:20:00,400 AUDREY: Goodness. Do show her in, Maud. 351 00:20:01,435 --> 00:20:02,469 MAUD: Do come in. 352 00:20:04,605 --> 00:20:05,573 Thank you. 353 00:20:08,341 --> 00:20:11,344 -Cecil Beaton, hello. -Well, well. 354 00:20:13,514 --> 00:20:14,682 Something to say? 355 00:20:17,618 --> 00:20:20,988 Lee Miller. I hear you're the woman to see about a job. 356 00:20:21,022 --> 00:20:22,422 Audrey Withers. 357 00:20:22,456 --> 00:20:24,491 And, yes, I am. Please, do sit down. 358 00:20:24,525 --> 00:20:25,526 Thank you. 359 00:20:28,361 --> 00:20:29,429 May I? 360 00:20:29,463 --> 00:20:31,532 We don't hire older models. 361 00:20:31,566 --> 00:20:33,433 Oh, don't blow a gasket. 362 00:20:33,467 --> 00:20:36,269 -I'm not a model any more. -Oh, dear. 363 00:20:36,303 --> 00:20:38,438 -So what exactly are you then? -Cecil. 364 00:20:39,339 --> 00:20:40,340 Would you give us a moment? 365 00:20:42,009 --> 00:20:43,477 Please. 366 00:20:43,511 --> 00:20:45,880 I'll be back to fix this disaster. 367 00:20:50,417 --> 00:20:52,352 -I do apologise for Cecil. -(DOOR OPENS AND CLOSES) 368 00:20:52,385 --> 00:20:55,288 -He can be a bit of a... -Monster? 369 00:20:55,322 --> 00:20:57,457 No. He never could hide his disappointment 370 00:20:57,491 --> 00:20:59,227 that women get old. 371 00:20:59,259 --> 00:21:00,995 That's true. 372 00:21:01,028 --> 00:21:03,731 And not entirely unique to men in fashion. 373 00:21:03,765 --> 00:21:07,802 But he is irritatingly talented, so I manage. 374 00:21:07,835 --> 00:21:09,203 (PAPER RUSTLING) 375 00:21:11,404 --> 00:21:12,607 -(GASPS) -(LEE CLEARS THROAT) 376 00:21:15,176 --> 00:21:17,310 AUDREY: Where was this taken? 377 00:21:17,344 --> 00:21:19,479 That's, er, Syria. 378 00:21:19,514 --> 00:21:23,918 Erm, my studio work is right here. 379 00:21:25,787 --> 00:21:27,420 Er... 380 00:21:27,454 --> 00:21:30,858 Oh, these really are rather spectacular. 381 00:21:30,892 --> 00:21:32,325 Mm, thank you. 382 00:21:32,359 --> 00:21:34,929 But Cecil is right, I'm afraid. 383 00:21:34,962 --> 00:21:36,998 We're not hiring at the moment. 384 00:21:37,031 --> 00:21:39,167 To be frank, what with all that's going on, 385 00:21:39,200 --> 00:21:41,334 we're not sure how much longer they'll let us keep at it. 386 00:21:42,435 --> 00:21:44,939 Let me get through the next issue, 387 00:21:44,972 --> 00:21:47,241 see where we stand and we'll talk again. 388 00:21:47,909 --> 00:21:49,010 How does that sound? 389 00:21:50,211 --> 00:21:51,179 She didn't say no. 390 00:21:51,979 --> 00:21:54,048 She didn't say yes. 391 00:21:54,081 --> 00:21:55,583 You're looking at this the wrong way. 392 00:21:55,616 --> 00:21:59,120 Oh, please. You weren't there. 393 00:21:59,153 --> 00:22:02,857 I just wanna do my part, how hard can it be? 394 00:22:02,890 --> 00:22:04,225 You'll find something, my love. 395 00:22:04,258 --> 00:22:06,260 God, that is so patronising. 396 00:22:06,294 --> 00:22:08,461 -(LEE SIGHS) -(LIGHTER CLICKING) 397 00:22:12,800 --> 00:22:14,168 Darling, I need to tell you something. 398 00:22:14,836 --> 00:22:16,571 What? 399 00:22:16,604 --> 00:22:17,738 I've heard that people in Paris 400 00:22:17,772 --> 00:22:18,973 are going underground. 401 00:22:21,008 --> 00:22:22,375 What do you mean? 402 00:22:22,409 --> 00:22:23,511 It's getting dangerous. 403 00:22:25,646 --> 00:22:29,150 Paul, Nusch, Solange, Jean, 404 00:22:29,183 --> 00:22:31,285 they'll all be in hiding from the Nazis. 405 00:22:33,221 --> 00:22:34,555 YOUNG MAN: Why didn't you go back to Paris? 406 00:22:36,356 --> 00:22:39,660 I couldn't. Not then. 407 00:22:39,694 --> 00:22:42,129 Paris was occupied by the Nazis, 408 00:22:42,163 --> 00:22:43,998 and Britain was all alone, 409 00:22:44,031 --> 00:22:45,533 and we were totally cut off. 410 00:22:47,467 --> 00:22:50,004 So, what else is there to know? 411 00:22:50,638 --> 00:22:52,139 LEE: Oh, plenty. 412 00:22:52,173 --> 00:22:53,808 And although my friends were living under occupation, 413 00:22:53,841 --> 00:22:55,977 even they were doing something. 414 00:22:56,010 --> 00:22:58,913 Paul and Nusch had joined the resistance. 415 00:23:00,314 --> 00:23:01,549 But I didn't know that then 416 00:23:02,884 --> 00:23:04,484 and I had no way of reaching them. 417 00:23:06,153 --> 00:23:07,154 And, er... 418 00:23:08,556 --> 00:23:10,191 And then everyone started doing their bit. 419 00:23:10,224 --> 00:23:12,360 Roland was out most nights being an Air Raid Warden. 420 00:23:12,392 --> 00:23:14,362 And I felt useless. 421 00:23:14,394 --> 00:23:16,764 And the more depressed I got, the smaller my ass got. 422 00:23:16,797 --> 00:23:20,334 Which is usually the opposite. 423 00:23:20,368 --> 00:23:22,435 But did she end up giving you the job? 424 00:23:22,469 --> 00:23:24,372 Oh, yeah, she caved pretty quickly. 425 00:23:24,404 --> 00:23:27,708 I think she realised that wrangling Cecil Beaton 426 00:23:27,742 --> 00:23:30,044 would be a lot more fun with another woman around. 427 00:23:30,077 --> 00:23:31,078 (YOUNG MAN CHUCKLES) 428 00:23:34,382 --> 00:23:35,383 Cecil Beaton... 429 00:23:36,183 --> 00:23:37,285 Ugh. 430 00:23:37,318 --> 00:23:39,186 (MEN SHOUTING INDISTINCTLY) 431 00:23:42,256 --> 00:23:44,659 -Is everyone all right? -Mercifully, yes. 432 00:23:44,692 --> 00:23:45,960 Where's Audrey? 433 00:23:45,993 --> 00:23:47,695 -There. -(AUDREY SQUEALING) 434 00:23:47,728 --> 00:23:49,230 It's actually not as bad as it looks. 435 00:23:49,263 --> 00:23:50,631 The structure is sound. 436 00:23:50,665 --> 00:23:52,566 But we will need to move in the basement for a while. 437 00:23:52,600 --> 00:23:53,668 Are we out of business? 438 00:23:53,701 --> 00:23:55,703 Oh! I don't see why we should be. 439 00:23:55,736 --> 00:23:56,837 I spoke to the Ministry this morning, 440 00:23:56,871 --> 00:23:58,139 and we have our paper ration. 441 00:23:58,172 --> 00:24:00,875 -Well, that's a relief. -We also have a mission. 442 00:24:00,908 --> 00:24:03,544 To encourage the women of Britain to do their duty. 443 00:24:05,546 --> 00:24:08,049 Might I borrow these for a moment? 444 00:24:08,082 --> 00:24:09,884 -Certainly. -LEE: Thank you. 445 00:24:09,917 --> 00:24:12,053 Maud, come with me. 446 00:24:12,920 --> 00:24:14,722 Er, and you. 447 00:24:14,755 --> 00:24:17,725 -Would you care to join us? -She's so creative. 448 00:24:17,758 --> 00:24:19,026 LEE: Just hold it in position... 449 00:24:19,060 --> 00:24:20,094 -Okay. -...with this ridiculous 450 00:24:20,127 --> 00:24:21,429 strap thing. 451 00:24:21,461 --> 00:24:22,997 -MAUD: I can't see a thing. -Can't see a thing? 452 00:24:23,030 --> 00:24:24,532 -I can't see. -LEE: My gosh. 453 00:24:24,565 --> 00:24:27,601 Here, this is your... Right here. Right, here we go. 454 00:24:28,302 --> 00:24:29,370 There! 455 00:24:29,403 --> 00:24:31,272 (UPLIFTING MUSIC PLAYING) 456 00:24:31,305 --> 00:24:32,707 There, that's it. 457 00:24:32,740 --> 00:24:34,108 WOMAN: Oh, goodness. 458 00:24:34,141 --> 00:24:36,610 Maud, you can sit right there. All right, here we go. 459 00:24:36,644 --> 00:24:38,579 Pay no attention to the burning building 460 00:24:38,612 --> 00:24:39,914 over my shoulder. 461 00:24:39,947 --> 00:24:41,549 -(BOTH WOMEN CHUCKLE) -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 462 00:24:41,582 --> 00:24:44,452 LEE: The Blitz turned houses inside out, 463 00:24:44,484 --> 00:24:46,387 streets upside down, 464 00:24:46,420 --> 00:24:48,756 and created chaos for the people of London. 465 00:24:48,789 --> 00:24:49,924 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 466 00:24:51,125 --> 00:24:52,460 But everyone carried on 467 00:24:52,492 --> 00:24:54,862 and I did what I could to capture it. 468 00:24:58,065 --> 00:25:00,301 Men were sent off to fight. 469 00:25:00,334 --> 00:25:04,271 The wives were left behind caring for their children. 470 00:25:04,305 --> 00:25:05,906 Without that responsibility 471 00:25:05,940 --> 00:25:07,641 we were able to be single-minded. 472 00:25:08,342 --> 00:25:10,745 We worked all hours. 473 00:25:10,778 --> 00:25:13,481 (SCOFFS) Anything to get the next issue out. 474 00:25:16,584 --> 00:25:17,918 The months rolled by... 475 00:25:17,952 --> 00:25:20,254 -(EXPLOSION) -...bombs rained down. 476 00:25:20,287 --> 00:25:22,289 It became part of daily life. 477 00:25:24,125 --> 00:25:25,960 There were times when we froze our asses off, 478 00:25:25,993 --> 00:25:28,295 but we just kept going. 479 00:25:28,329 --> 00:25:29,397 (INDISTINCT CHATTERING) 480 00:25:29,430 --> 00:25:31,766 Audrey was a terrific boss 481 00:25:31,799 --> 00:25:33,768 and we became friends. 482 00:25:33,801 --> 00:25:35,903 There wasn't much more to it than that. 483 00:25:35,936 --> 00:25:36,971 (BIRDS CHIRPING) 484 00:25:37,004 --> 00:25:38,239 Oh, Audrey. 485 00:25:42,309 --> 00:25:43,411 Children? 486 00:25:43,444 --> 00:25:45,312 Oh, God, no. You? 487 00:25:46,380 --> 00:25:47,648 Oh, God, no. 488 00:25:51,619 --> 00:25:52,586 May I? 489 00:25:58,159 --> 00:26:00,027 YOUNG MAN: So you never actually wanted children? 490 00:26:03,731 --> 00:26:05,399 Well, I never thought I could. 491 00:26:09,403 --> 00:26:10,471 (LEE CHUCKLES SOFTLY) 492 00:26:10,505 --> 00:26:12,541 I was never cut out for mothering. 493 00:26:14,041 --> 00:26:15,042 (SIGHS) 494 00:26:16,744 --> 00:26:18,646 Why are you asking an old woman so many questions? 495 00:26:18,679 --> 00:26:20,147 (CHUCKLES) 496 00:26:20,181 --> 00:26:23,684 -Come on, you're not that old. -Oh. (CHUCKLES) 497 00:26:23,717 --> 00:26:25,886 Now, isn't that like a man? 498 00:26:25,920 --> 00:26:28,355 First, I'm not young enough, then I'm not old enough. 499 00:26:29,657 --> 00:26:31,025 Just trying to understand. 500 00:26:32,593 --> 00:26:33,594 What? 501 00:26:34,563 --> 00:26:35,629 Trying to understand you. 502 00:26:37,398 --> 00:26:39,467 (EXHILARATING MUSIC PLAYING) 503 00:26:39,500 --> 00:26:41,202 (SIREN WAILING) 504 00:26:41,235 --> 00:26:42,504 WOMAN: Target... 505 00:26:42,537 --> 00:26:43,871 (INDISTINCT CHATTER) 506 00:26:43,904 --> 00:26:45,406 (PLANE ENGINES WHIRRING) 507 00:26:46,508 --> 00:26:48,042 LEE: I was ambitious. 508 00:26:48,075 --> 00:26:50,512 I was good at shooting on my own. 509 00:26:50,545 --> 00:26:51,546 Er... 510 00:26:52,514 --> 00:26:53,881 Maybe form a line. 511 00:26:53,914 --> 00:26:54,982 In my experience, 512 00:26:55,015 --> 00:26:57,651 working partnerships were tricky. 513 00:26:57,685 --> 00:26:59,588 And there can only be one boss. 514 00:27:01,523 --> 00:27:02,957 Evening, ladies. 515 00:27:02,990 --> 00:27:05,993 LEE: But then Davy Scherman from Life Magazine showed up. 516 00:27:06,026 --> 00:27:07,928 -Hello. -Hiya. 517 00:27:09,130 --> 00:27:10,264 Not exactly the place I thought 518 00:27:10,297 --> 00:27:11,298 I'd find another Yank. 519 00:27:11,966 --> 00:27:12,967 LEE: Uh-huh. 520 00:27:14,201 --> 00:27:15,236 DAVY: It's a little bit dark. 521 00:27:15,970 --> 00:27:17,071 LEE: I know. 522 00:27:17,104 --> 00:27:18,105 -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) -May I? 523 00:27:19,874 --> 00:27:21,543 (SIGHS) 524 00:27:21,576 --> 00:27:25,012 LEE: Suddenly it wasn't a competition, we were a team. 525 00:27:25,813 --> 00:27:26,981 It felt easy. 526 00:27:28,916 --> 00:27:31,586 -Left a little. -Yes, ma'am. 527 00:27:31,620 --> 00:27:33,787 -Say "Blitz". -WOMEN: Blitz! 528 00:27:33,821 --> 00:27:35,656 -(ALL LAUGH) -Thank you. 529 00:27:39,093 --> 00:27:40,861 -Thank you. -You're welcome. 530 00:27:40,895 --> 00:27:42,163 (PLANE ENGINES DRONING) 531 00:27:44,465 --> 00:27:45,866 (INDISTINCT CHATTERING) 532 00:27:54,609 --> 00:27:56,310 (INDISTINCT ANNOUNCEMENT OVER SPEAKERS) 533 00:28:01,782 --> 00:28:03,951 OFFICER: I'm afraid this is as far as you can go, ma'am. 534 00:28:03,984 --> 00:28:05,786 LEE: No, I... I'm with Vogue Magazine. 535 00:28:05,819 --> 00:28:07,656 Look, she's with me. 536 00:28:07,721 --> 00:28:08,923 You need military accreditation 537 00:28:08,956 --> 00:28:09,990 beyond this point. 538 00:28:10,024 --> 00:28:12,126 (SCOFFS) Oh, God. 539 00:28:12,159 --> 00:28:13,460 The publications were informed, ma'am. 540 00:28:13,494 --> 00:28:15,963 Only non-military access for women. 541 00:28:15,996 --> 00:28:17,965 Please make your way over toward the mess block. 542 00:28:21,969 --> 00:28:23,304 Jeez. (SIGHS) 543 00:28:23,337 --> 00:28:24,972 You think they'd let up after I spent hours 544 00:28:25,005 --> 00:28:26,140 in that goddamn car. 545 00:28:28,610 --> 00:28:29,578 Sorry. 546 00:28:36,817 --> 00:28:38,786 (GENTLE MUSIC PLAYING) 547 00:28:45,059 --> 00:28:46,060 (DOOR CREAKING) 548 00:29:27,034 --> 00:29:28,035 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 549 00:29:56,263 --> 00:29:57,264 (DOOR OPENS) 550 00:29:58,899 --> 00:29:59,933 Oh. 551 00:29:59,967 --> 00:30:01,368 -Hello. -LEE: Oh, excuse me. 552 00:30:01,402 --> 00:30:03,270 I'm Lee Miller. I work for Vogue. 553 00:30:03,304 --> 00:30:06,574 Oh! Ann Douglas, ATA. 554 00:30:06,608 --> 00:30:08,576 Wow, you fly. 555 00:30:08,610 --> 00:30:10,377 Only ferrying our bombers between bases. But... 556 00:30:11,245 --> 00:30:12,413 Yes, I do. 557 00:30:12,446 --> 00:30:14,081 Would you mind if I took your picture? 558 00:30:14,749 --> 00:30:16,183 Oh, no problem. 559 00:30:20,655 --> 00:30:22,624 Your work, it really, erm... 560 00:30:22,657 --> 00:30:24,458 It lets us know what's going on out there. 561 00:30:29,430 --> 00:30:30,397 Thank you. 562 00:30:32,266 --> 00:30:34,468 Let's push you back over here by the door. 563 00:30:36,771 --> 00:30:39,006 Let's try that. 564 00:30:40,675 --> 00:30:42,943 -(ANN CHUCKLES) -There you go. 565 00:30:42,976 --> 00:30:44,746 See if we can get you in the magazine. 566 00:30:44,779 --> 00:30:46,980 Oh. Does this sort of thing get published? 567 00:30:47,014 --> 00:30:48,215 LEE: Hopefully. 568 00:30:48,248 --> 00:30:49,950 -(BOTH CHUCKLE) -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 569 00:30:49,983 --> 00:30:51,820 Would you mind taking off your hat? 570 00:30:53,287 --> 00:30:55,790 -Wonderful. Here we go. -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 571 00:30:57,826 --> 00:30:58,827 There. 572 00:31:00,194 --> 00:31:01,663 Don't wanna take any more of your time. 573 00:31:01,696 --> 00:31:02,930 Pleasure meeting you. 574 00:31:02,963 --> 00:31:04,131 Lovely to meet you, Miss Miller. 575 00:31:07,267 --> 00:31:08,335 -(PAPER RUSTLING) -(PEN SCRATCHING) 576 00:31:09,704 --> 00:31:13,140 Are you still staying in that shitty hotel? 577 00:31:13,173 --> 00:31:16,377 Not for long if I keep bringing home broken mirrors. 578 00:31:16,410 --> 00:31:20,447 Mm. Well, you're welcome to stay here. 579 00:31:20,481 --> 00:31:23,685 -We have the room. -DAVY: You sure? 580 00:31:23,718 --> 00:31:24,819 And Roland wouldn't mind? 581 00:31:25,620 --> 00:31:26,755 The only people who care 582 00:31:26,788 --> 00:31:27,856 about the men I'm sleeping with 583 00:31:27,921 --> 00:31:29,390 are the men I'm not sleeping with. 584 00:31:32,627 --> 00:31:35,095 (DOOR OPENING, CLOSING) 585 00:31:39,333 --> 00:31:40,334 Away? 586 00:31:41,435 --> 00:31:42,504 Where? 587 00:31:42,537 --> 00:31:43,538 The coast. 588 00:31:44,405 --> 00:31:45,774 I'm only a few hours away. 589 00:31:46,808 --> 00:31:47,776 For how long? 590 00:31:48,643 --> 00:31:50,177 ROLAND: A while, I expect. 591 00:31:57,685 --> 00:31:59,687 We're getting ready, aren't we? 592 00:31:59,721 --> 00:32:01,656 For the invasion of Europe. 593 00:32:01,689 --> 00:32:03,490 Oh, I know as much as you do, I'm afraid. 594 00:32:04,925 --> 00:32:07,995 I'll be disguising tanks to look like ice cream kiosks, 595 00:32:08,028 --> 00:32:09,631 but I didn't tell you that. 596 00:32:09,664 --> 00:32:13,568 Davy, take our picture before he leaves. 597 00:32:16,538 --> 00:32:17,605 Yep. 598 00:32:24,913 --> 00:32:27,448 -ROLAND: Aw. -(CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 599 00:32:27,481 --> 00:32:29,584 LEE: (SOFTLY) Don't go. ROLAND: It won't be long. 600 00:32:31,351 --> 00:32:32,319 (SOFTLY) Stop. 601 00:32:33,888 --> 00:32:34,889 (CAMERA SHUTTER CLICKING) 602 00:32:36,423 --> 00:32:38,893 CECIL: No. No. No! 603 00:32:38,927 --> 00:32:42,362 Not some poor woman's intimates! 604 00:32:42,396 --> 00:32:43,565 If Lee Miller thinks she can... 605 00:32:43,598 --> 00:32:45,466 It's not about what Lee Miller thinks 606 00:32:45,499 --> 00:32:46,901 or doesn't think, Cecil. 607 00:32:46,935 --> 00:32:50,370 This is about our duty to our readers. 608 00:32:50,404 --> 00:32:52,841 Those of us without housekeepers 609 00:32:52,874 --> 00:32:53,942 or hot water 610 00:32:53,974 --> 00:32:57,177 care about a lot more than couture. 611 00:32:57,211 --> 00:33:00,915 -It's not Vogue's place... -It's not your place! 612 00:33:00,949 --> 00:33:02,851 The pants stay on the line.
